recordings.loc: near Buena Vista, Baja California Sur
recordings.rmk: 60+ Common Ravens, 60+ Crested Caracras (and some completely silent Turkey Vultures), most not vocalizing at all, at a dump; many, many intervals shortened to remove some of the worst dump noise, but many ugly spots remain, but a good variety of Raven calls of different pitch as well, e.g., a good section 1:50 to 2:25; Raven calls perched and in flight;
Caw

Birds circling the tree with their nest during ringing of their chicks. Pine forest.  Clear and sunny weather.

No modifications to the recording.

recordings.loc: Isla San Benito Oeste, Baja California
recordings.rmk: interval shortened at 0:18, then in flight one of the four in flight in the previous recording; and at 0:36, after which one of the four, briefly in flight in the high-pitched part, then perched near me; interval shortened at 2:58, after which lower-pitched bird one that I had not been recording, then the high-pitched one that I had, a third bird, silent, all flying off together; recording starts weak, gets good;

recordings.loc: Humphrey Head Point near Grange-Over-Sands, Cumbria
recordings.rmk:
The recording has not been modified.
The recording was made on the shore on the western flank of Humphrey Head Point.
The raven's call is being amplified by the limestone cliff which forms Humphrey Head Point. Other song birds can also be heard. The raven's call is the deep, guttural one.

A pair of ravens calling in a pine forest. In the beginning of the recording the birds were further but after a minute and a half  they came flying closer up to me. Four juveniles near by. This pair nest in this forest every year. This recording is a part of a series of five recordings I made this day.

Sounds of machinery are also audible in the background.

Modifications to the file: none.

These raucous squawks were produced by members of a nine-strong troupe (I believe two family parties were involved) that settled on the roof of a farmer's home on a Sunday morning at 0640hrs. The racket was deafening and the clip was recorded roughly ten minutes after the birds arrived. I made the recording from an adjoining cottage: so you can imagine the volume for the people in the house upon whose roof the birds were sitting. The farmer had buried a dead sheep nearby the day before and the Ravens had smelled the rotten corpse. However, it was too deep for them to disinter. The noise made by the horde caused some calling among other birds in the farmer's garden: such as juvenile Blackbirds [examples at 0:03 and 0:04], Goldfinches [examples at 0:27, 0:44 and 1:06] and a Wren [example at 0:18]. Skylark song can be heard as a backdrop from 0:06 onwards and is best from 1:15 to the end. A Corncrake calls from time to time. Although faint, the Corncrake can be detected after 0:59 for about five seconds. The gull cry at 0:52 (for the next three seconds) are from a Herring Gull.

recordings.type: calling to drive away a predator, wing beats.
recordings.rmk:
This 2.5 minute recording documents one adult Common Raven (sex undetermined) attempting to drive me away from its full grown fledged yet still dependent youngster. It made several passes over me while the media was recording. There is one other significant vocalization in this recording and that is of one adult male Brewer's Blackbird. This Brewer's Blackbird was diving on the raven as it was perched at the top of a tree.

This recording was made with an iPhone 5s with a Sennheiser shotgun microphone and Røde Rec application. This recording has not been modified or edited. It is a portion of a longer 6 minute recording.

Common Raven is an uncommon permanent resident in the Blue Ridge ecoregion of Georgia; the terminus of the Appalachian Mountains in the state represent the southernmost extent of its breeding range east of the Mississippi River. It nests on exposed rocky cliffs at the state's highest elevations, although direct evidence of breeding -- such as active nests, eggs, or dependent young -- is extremely rare. This encounter was one of several on this date and the following day, all of which involved a pair. Most observations (like this one) were of the pair circling, soaring, and calling to one another. Later on this date, the pair was apparently perched somewhere unseen and the birds were engaging in "chatter" calls back and forth, which were difficult to record. Two birds, relating so closely to each other, and remaining in such a small area, is suggestive of nesting nearby -- most likely on Grassy Ridge or Wolf Knob. As is often the case, the cliffs on these peaks are extremely difficult and dangerous to access, and are not visible from any nearby vantage points.
Telinga on tripod, Zoom H6

recordings.loc: Mount Work, Vancouver Island, British Columbia
recordings.rmk: Wide range of vocalizations from ~20 ravens gathered around Mount Work summit, flying, chasing, barrel-rolling, and perching on Douglas-fir snags.  Recording is a series of separate cuts, all recorded within a two hour timespan.  Cuts are separated by brief silent intervals in the track.  Bill-snapping and associated guttural sounds (such as after 8:50 and 4:00) are from several birds perched close together and preening.  A remarkably high vocalization is at 10:28.

I approached a presumed nest site of this species with ravens calling distantly and I thought I may have heard a juvenile bird at first; then an adult flew into the presumed nest site and then eventually a pair of birds discovered me below them at which time I began recording. The pair circled me while calling harshly; I tracked them with my microphone (mobile phone) as they circled around. Habitat was mixed deciduous/conifer forest; birds were 30 feet overhead in mid to upper canopy. Recording trails off near end because birds became distant for a short time (they returned later). I amplified the recording with Audacity (perhaps too much?).

recordings.loc: Centennial Woods, Burlington, Chittenden County, Vermont
recordings.type: call, life stage uncertain, sex uncertain
recordings.rmk: The focal sounds in this recording were the nasally honks, for lack of a better term, as well as the more typical raven calls (to a lesser extent). This recording was not modified significantly, to my knowledge. The habitat was typical for this area of Centennial, an open, marshy environment in between stands of eastern white pine (among other trees). Here, the birds were flying. I think the strange nasally calls may have been from juveniles begging, but it is hard to tell (and I would love some assistance if possible). Four individuals were seen overall, and all appeared to be in varying stages of molt (particularly on the wings). A crow was also seen nearby, though I cannot remember how or if they interacted. More information, including photographs by my friend Kayley Dillon, can be found at [this eBird link](https://ebird.org/checklist/S55787227).
